values: Sorry, I don't know about that one!
Come again?
Ok, I don't know the answer to that so I will send to Discovery.
Hi!
Hey..
Hello
Are you asking about something outside of Conversation?? C'mon...
Welcome! I am the Conversation Docs Bot. What do you need help with?
Not a problem!
You're very welcome.
A chatbot is a computer program designed to simulate conversation with humans.

A dialog uses the intents and entities that have been identified, plus context from the application, to interact with the user and ultimately provide a response. Conversation provides a unique interface that enables users to quickly and efficiently build conversational experiences.
Try this
This shows how to get a response from a user's input.
Check this out.
Getting started
Here are the latest release notes.
This link will show you what the latest version of Conversation is.
Here are some sample applications.
An entity represents a term or object in the user's input that provides clarification or specific context for a particular intent.
An intent is a purpose or goal expressed in a customer's input. To create an intent, you add examples of how a user would express that goal.

An intent is a purpose or goal expressed in a customer's input, while an entity represents a class of object or a data type that is relevant to a user's purpose. If intents represent verbs, entities represent nouns.
Arrays can be used in the context section of a node. You can update the array by appending values, removing a value, or replacing all the values.
Botkit is an open-source toolkit for creating bots. It makes it easy for your application to connect to messaging platforms like Slack. Here is their website if you'd like to learn more!
Check out our tutorial here!

Click on the node you want to move, and select the arrows icon at the bottom of the node. Then, click on the node you want to be above your moved one, and select the location icon to move the selected node.
Click on the upper right corner of the UI (the chat bubble) to go to the 'Try it out' panel. This is where you can test your bot to see if you're getting your expected responses.
Connect Watson Conversation to a messaging platform through our middleware plugin for Botkit.
Context is executed once a conversation reaches that node.
Entities can be viewed as the noun if we consider intents to be verbs. They help identify and capture key terms or phrases in a user's input.
Go to this link to see an example of how to interact with the Conversation API.

If the Service Details page is not already open, click your Conversation service instance on the Bluemix console. (When you create a service instance, the Service Details page displays.)

On the "Service Details" page, scroll down to Conversation tooling and click Launch tool.
Click Create to create a new workspace.
Specify the details for the new workspace:
  • Name: A name no more than 64 characters in length. This value is required.
  • Description: A description no more than 128 characters in length.
  • Language: The language of the user input the workspace will be trained to understand.
    Click Create. The new workspace is created and now appears as a tile on the Workspaces page.
If you'd like to see an example of developing an application to talk to Conversation, go here.
If you're having trouble with something that I can't answer, please fill out this form to get in touch with some humans!
If you're on the Free plan, the messages stored are from the last 7 days. On Standard/Premium, messages are stored from the last 30 days. You can find these chat logs in the 'Improve' tab.

In order to import entities, put the entities into a CSV file with the following format: entity, value, synonyms.

Find more info here.
In order to import intents, collect the examples and matching intents in a CSV file with the following format: example, intent. Find more info here.

Nodes are evaluated in a top to bottom manner. First, the dialog tries to find an answer in the child nodes of the contextual node. If no match is found, the dialog continues to a second stage where it looks for an answer by matching the top level dialog nodes.

Once you make a call to Conversation, your response object contains which intents and entities were detected. To single out the detected entity value, parse the JSON similar to this example: 'entities.airport[0].value'
On the Free plan, you can have 25,000 dialog nodes per service instance. For Standard/Premium, you can have 100,000 dialog nodes per service instance.

System entities can be enabled from the 'Entities' tab. Click 'System Entities' next to 'My Entities', and switch the system entity you want to on. Now, whenever a system entity is detected, you will see it in the output starting with 'sys'
The Conversation API returns a response object with the context, input, and output pertaining to the user's input. You can access this information like a normal JSON object.
The supported languages are Brazilian Portuguese, English, French, Italian, Spanish, German, Traditional Chinese, Simplified Chinese, and Dutch.

To create an entity, make sure you are in the 'Entities' tab at the top of the tooling. Then, click 'Create New' to start adding examples of that entity. Make sure you add synonyms so your bot can pick those up as well! Go here for more information.

To create an example, simply click 'Add a new user example' and fill in the appropriate text. If you'd like to move the example to a different intent, check the box to the left of the example, then select 'move to' and pick its destination. For more information, go here.

To create an intent, make sure you are in the 'Intents' tab at the top of our tooling. Select 'Create New', and add at least 5 examples of what the user would say. The more the merrier! To learn more, click here.
To export an existing workspace to a JSON file, click the menu icon in the workspace tile and then select Download as JSON

To import a workspace from a JSON file, click the Import workspace icon. Select the JSON file you want to import from and specify what data you want to include:  Select Everything (Intents, Entities, and Dialog) if you want to import a complete copy of the exported workspace, including the dialog. Select Intents and Entities if you want to use the intents and entities from the exported workspace, but you plan to build a new dialog. Important: The imported JSON file must use UTF-8 encoding.
To process user input, you need to add a user interface to your application. For example, connect to a messaging platform like Slack, or use Node.js' prompt-sync module for testing.
To start a conversation, use the condition 'conversation_start' in the first node. This causes the bot to prompt the user with that node once the conversation starts.
To use context, open the {...} icon inside of a node and add a context object. Within context, you can define any supported JSON types. Go here for examples.
Watson Conversation is a chatbot-building platform powered by IBM Watson.

When you want to change the flow of a dialog, use a Jump To action. This will tell the system which dialog node to go to next. If you want to change the flow of the dialog with Jump To, the target node must be created first.

You can access the service credentials and the workspace ID from your workspace by selecting the 3-line menu and choosing Credentials.  You can also access the service credentials from your Bluemix dashboard.
You can find the API Reference here.

You can use any combination of intents, entities, context variables, and special conditions in the condition portion of a node. Valid expressions in conditions are written in the Spring Expression language (SpEL).

Your application may not be following the correct conversation flow if it isn't maintaining state. This is done through the context JSON object passing back and forth between your application and the Conversation service. There is a unique identifier for each conversation with a user, as well as a counter that is incremented with each turn of the conversation. Go here for an example.
You're able to use context in a condition with the shorthand '\$variable_name:value'. This will allow you to condition based off some of the variables you are storing for that particular user.
